p: It is important to note that climate change affects not only surface water but groundwater as well. An interview with the Municipal Planning Unit revealed that some boreholes have already dried up and many more are becoming dysfunctional; this is widely attributed to the impacts of climate change. It was added that in the past it could take only forty pumps to fill-up a 40 L bucket, but with the current drought conditions, 60 pumps are now required. This supports the view that the groundwater table in the Municipality was dropping [ 34]. Rural Aid responded that more than half of water resources in the Municipality were not able to contain water all year round and this situation is expected to worsen further with climate change.
